channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Foreign Minister Calls for New Chemical Weapons Accord
item.description: Sergey V. Lavrov said the existing treaty was insufficient to address the rising use of those arms by terrorist groups.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, center, at the European headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: Jailed Afghan Women Are Often Subjected to Virginity Tests, Report Says
item.description: Jailed girls as young as 13 have been forced to undergo invasive and invalid tests, Afghanistan’s human rights commission said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Memo From London: Britain’s Looming E.U. Referendum Exposes Tory Squabbles
item.description: The Conservative Party could be taking advantage of its first majority government since 1992, but is ripping itself apart over whether to stay in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, left, and Prime Minister David Cameron during the 2015 election campaign. The Conservative Party is deeply split over whether Britain should remain in the European Union.

item.title: Iraq’s Biggest Dam Could Collapse at Any Time, Killing Thousands
item.description: Vital maintenance work at the Mosul Dam was stopped when Islamic State fighters seized it in 2014, but did not resume after the government retook it.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An employee at the Mosul Dam in northern Iraq last month.

item.title: Jakarta Journal: Indonesians Flock to Restaurant Where Woman Was Poisoned
item.description: The case of the “coffee murder,” in which a young woman died of cyanide poisoning in Jakarta, has set off morbid curiosity.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers at the Olivier restaurant in Jakarta, where a young woman, Wayan Mirna Salihin, died in January of cyanide poisoning.

item.title: Europe’s New Border Controls Exact a Cost
item.description: As the European Union grapples with the migration crisis, the resulting revival of checkpoints on vital transport routes threatens to cost billions of euros in lost business.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Laerke Posselt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Document controls at the Copenhagen Airport train station, the last stop before Malmo, Sweden. Inspections are imposing significant delays on cross-border commuters and shoppers.

item.title: Britain Drops Case Against Last Suspect in 1998 Omagh Bombing
item.description: Charges against Seamus Daly over the attack in Northern Ireland that killed 29 were withdrawn because of doubts over the reliability of crucial evidence.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Osama bin Laden Feared Wife’s Tooth Held a Tracking Device
item.description: Newly released documents suggest that as the United States turned up the pressure, the leader of Al Qaeda grew increasingly concerned about security breaches.
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Warrick Page for The New York Times
item.media:description: The compound where Osama Bin Laden was killed in Abbottabad, Pakistan, in 2011.

item.title: Violence Erupts After 2 Israeli Soldiers Using Waze App Get Lost in West Bank
item.description: A Palestinian man was killed after the soldiers, using Waze, a navigation tool, drove into the Kalandia refugee camp, prompting clashes and a gun battle.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: A car burned during an Israeli Army raid the night before in the West Bank refugee camp of Kalandia on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India's Water Wars
item.description: In cutting off New Delhi's water supply, the Jat community deployed a form of protest refined over centuries.
item.dc:creator: AMAN SETHI

item.title: Letter From Africa: Raw Tensions Over Race Fester in South Africa
item.description: Bitter controversies on social media have shown that two decades of democracy have muted neither the perception nor the reality of inequality.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Spain’s Socialist Leader Has Chance, if Improbable, to Be Premier
item.description: Pedro Sánchez looked like a spent political force after a dismal election showing, but a fractured Parliament could yet vote him into power.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: The leader of the Socialist party, Pedro Sánchez, center, arriving at a news conference at the Spanish Parliament in Madrid last month.

item.title: Sinosphere: In a Harvard Scholar’s 18th-Century History, Glimpses of Modern China
item.description: The Harvard historian Philip A. Kuhn’s book on a 1768 sorcery scare has drawn parallels to today’s China, and his death has revived the questions he posed.
item.category: Soulstealers: The Chinese Sorcery Scare of 1768 (Book)
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Red Guards brandishing Mao Zedong’s writings demonstrating in front of the Soviet Embassy in Beijing on Aug. 29, 1966. In a postscript to a Chinese translation of Philip A. Kuhn’s “Soulstealers: The Chinese Sorcery Scare of 1768,” the historian Liu Chang drew parallels between the mass hysteria of the 18th century and Mao’s Cultural Revolution.

item.title: Hamas Commander, Accused of Theft and Gay Sex, Is Killed by His Own
item.description: The death of Mahmoud Ishtiwi, who was accused of homosexuality, had all the trappings of a soap opera: sex, torture and embezzlement, in the armed wing of Hamas.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Mahmoud Ishtiwi, a former commander in the armed wing of Hamas, at a mosque in the Gaza Strip in February.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Zhang Fan on Chinese ‘Parachute Kids’ in the U.S.
item.description: Zhang Fan, whose son is in prison for a grisly assault in California, discusses the problems faced by youths sent to the United States for better opportunities.
item.dc:creator: CAO LI
item.media:description: Zhang Xinlei arriving for his sentencing hearing at the Los Angeles County Superior Court on Feb. 17.

item.title: Chinese Court Upholds Life Sentence for Top Aide to Bo Xilai
item.description: The court rejected an appeal by the aide, Wu Wenkang, who had been given a life sentence by a lower court in late 2014.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Jinan Intermediate People's Court, via Reuters
item.media:description: Bo Xilai, center, who was once among China’s top-ranking Communist Party leaders, listening to his verdict in Jinan, in Shandong Province, in 2013.

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: United Nations Says Food Aid Will Be Restored
item.description: In a statement, the World Food Program, the main United Nations anti-hunger agency, said $675 million pledged would allow it to “fully reinstate” the reduced aid.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Utilities Cautioned About Potential for a Cyberattack After Ukraine’s
item.description: Working remotely, attackers conducted “extensive reconnaissance” of the Ukraine power system’s networks, stole the credentials of operators and learned how to switch off the breakers, plunging more than 225,000 Ukrainians into darkness.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: After Gains Against ISIS, Pentagon Focuses on Mosul
item.description: The United States military is laying groundwork for a fight to retake Iraq’s second-largest city, moving to isolate it from the Islamic State’s headquarters in Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers during an exercise in January with American and Spanish trainers southeast of Baghdad.

item.title: DealBook: ‘Brexit’ Vote and Donald Trump’s Surge Reflect Discontent
item.description: The outcome of Britain’s June 23 referendum is murky, but moves toward more extreme solutions may reflect a global sense of helplessness seen elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
item.media:description: Mervyn King, the former governor of the Bank of England.
